column14:
Hello, may I ask about why infinity of IEEE754 standard is represented as : sign bit 0, exponent all 1, mantisa all 0. 

I am kind of confused because it is actually representing 1.0 * 2^128, why is it regarded as infinity? 

Thanks!
column16: Updated 2 years ago by CHANG, Bing Yen and Anonymous Mouse
column17:
The designers of the IEEE754 standard specified this as a special case to represent infinity.

One convenience is that "infinity" can still be represented as the same "float" or "double" data-type in higher-level programming languages.

Then we have a guarantee that any other floating point number (except NaNs) will compare as less-than positive infinity (or more than negative infinity).

This also builds-in a way for the arithmetic processor to detect and catch magnitude overflow and clamp as "infinity", instead of wrapping-around.

column14:
Can I please ask that in the while loop example why do we need to sll first ?

sorry a bit lost there 

I know that we are trying to calculate the address of save[i] but not sure completely 

thank you 

any help appreciated
column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
Suppose you have a *word* array, arr[5] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}. The base address (starting address) is at $s0.

The address of arr[0]: $s0

The address of arr[1]: $s0 + 4 (4 is offset, it's 1 x 4)

The address of arr[2]: $s0 + 8 (8 is offset, it's 2 x 4)

and so on...

If we use $s1 to hold i, array index. $t0 for arr[i], $t1 for address of arr[i]
Then $t1 = $s0 + 4 * $s1

We haven't learned multiplication MIPS instruction, so we use shift left for 2 position as a shortcut of multiplication by 4.

For example, 00010, after shift left by 2 positions, 01000. (Note, use shift as shortcut of multiplication assumes it's for unsigned, and the result still fits in the representable range).
column21: by sll $t1, $s3, 2, we calculated i*4.As each element in the array takes 4 bytes, so when the index increase by 1, the address increase by 4. So this is just making use of the index difference to calculate the address difference. And adding that address difference to the base address will get the address of the ith element in the array.

column14: For Q1, can I assume the length of array will always be 10 in the test case. If not, will the length of array be 0 or 1.

I think in general you shouldn't assume a fixed size for the arrays. In fact we could change the array sizes easily by changing the constant 10 in the following three labels and create a test case for arrays of size different than 10

Accum: .word 0:10
size: .word 10

Moreover you are required to implement the the AccumulateArray function, the parameter $a1 passed to it will be holding the array size, so it will be good if you could use $a1 for the array size. The arrays will be at least 1 in size (no possibility of having the size being 0), you can check that from the given C++ program. Hope this helps!

column14: Does that mean a label that consists both jal and jr $ra instructions? Or consisting either jal or jr $ra is already a procedure? column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Beaker
column17: A procedure/function typically starts from a label and ends with jr $ra. If you would like to call a procedure and jump back to the caller, then using the "jal " is a must. Because jal would store the return address to $ra. Without jal, your $ra would be holding garbage (or 0).

column14:
I was doing HW4 and I do not understand why the ALU Control should have different signals for 'subtract' function (0110) and 'set on less than' function (0111).

Essentially, both of these would be doing subtraction of x - y, the only difference is that for set less than, AFTER the ALU operations it would check if bit 0 of the output is 1 (x - y < 0). So why is there any difference in the ALU Control signal when calculation is similar INSIDE the ALU?

That is as far as my understanding goes.

[fig1]
Reference (Datapath 1 p.22)
column16: Updated 2 years ago by Loading...
column17: Though sub and slt both require the adder in the ALU doing the subtraction, but the results produced by them are not the same. For sub, it is producing the real subtraction result (for example if we have 15-9=6, then sub will need to have 6 to be the result). slt on the other hand needs producing a result indicating the sign of the subtraction (for example if we have the same 15-9, instead of 6, slt needs to produce the result of 0 as the sign bit of the subtraction is 0). If you look at the slide 25 of the arithmetic note set (https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp2611/note/COMP2611_Arithmetic_Spring22.pdf#page=25), to get the result for slt, we need to supply different value (than that of the sub) to be the switch (called "Operation" on the slide) that selects the result for the ALU.

column14:
I read the question wrong. Now I see that the values in the table are when the given instruction is fetch (step 1 in 5). Sorry about that

I have a few problems when trying to start Q3 in assignment4. 

I am given one 32-bit MIPS instruction but is asked to change the value of 8 registers? 

I thought $at is reversed for the assemabler and not supposed to be changed.

It asks me to write one MIPS instruction to change 8 values?

By MIPS instruction, do you mean in the 32-bit representation or like how we write in Mars?

Following the 32-bit instruction, i got a different value for $t5 than in the table.

Am I supposed to write an arbitrary programming, with e.g., addi $t5, $zero, 933, for part a?

Thank you in advance.
column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
In that question, the register values are provided to be the initial values before that particular instruction is loaded from the memory to the datapath (the hw description says "Assume the data memory contains all zeros and the registers have the following values when the instruction is fetched").

$at is a register typically for the assembler to support the "pseudo instruction" -> "real MIPS instruction" conversions, but you can use it, it is not a reserved register (unlike the $gp, $fp, $sp registers). Having said that, unless the instruction you are executing would modify $at, there is no need to change it.

You are NOT asked to change the register values, you only need to change the registers when the execution outcome of the instruction would change their values.

Write the instructions like what you would do in MARS, provide clearly the instruction name, the register names, immediate value, label(write the offset directly), or any other relevant information.

You need to use the instruction encoding to figure out what this instruction really is. It is impossible that you "got a different value for $t5 than in the table" from the instruction encoding provided. You may have misunderstood the question, or thought of it in a wrong direction.

column14:
On the table of slide 34, lecture slide Datapath and control, beq have memRead 0. My question is whether if X is also acceptable for memRead? Because as long as RegWrite and MemWrite is set to 0, nothing will change. Is it because of reading from memory take more time? Or did I misunderstand something somewhere?

Thanks.
column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Calc
column17: X means don't care, that indicates you can put it 0 or 1 as you wish. For the memRead it MUST BE 0 for "non memory read instructions". Otherwise since your ALU is supplying the memory address to the Data Memory through a hard-wired connection, it could supply an invalid address produced by "non memory read instructions", you can image what would happen if you enable memRead. For memory write instructions, memRead still needs to be 0 because we don't want to waste energy and time unnecessarily for an instruction that is not supposed to read.

If you are talking about the ALU control unit, then the "result" will be a proper control signal sent to the ALU to select an appropriate output. In the lecture note set, this control signal is called "ALU Operation". More inputs means you can supply additional information to the ALU control (which is effectively a circuit built by engineers like you).

column13: last question in the last tutorial note
column14:
Assume there is only forwarding path from the output of the ALU to the inputs of the ALU.

[fig1]
*given solution

From 2nd to 3rd instruction, i understand why it is needed to wait for one cycle. But why 2 cycles? Why can't we have the data from exe in the 2nd instruction forwarded to the exe in the 3rd instruction?
column16: Updated 1 year ago by Anonymous Scale
column17:
This question is a bit tricky:

The third instruction depends on the "lw" and the earlier "add" instructions on $s1 and $s2 respectively. Forwarding only exists from ALU output->ALU inputs, so the earliest time the third instruction can get the updated $s1 value (i.e. by doing ID) is in (the second half of) the clock cycle 5 after after "lw" is done with WB (in the first half of the clock cycle). But then if you align this third instruction accordingly, you will notice that it will not be able to get updated value of $s2 from the earlier "add" (i.e. the required forwarding is Mem->ALU, but this does not exist according to the problem description). Therefore the only way to get the updated value of $s2 is through ID, and therefore the third instruction can only do ID when the earlier "add" is done with WB in the first half of clock cycle 6.

column13: Question on hw4 suggested answer last question
column14:
[fig1]
How is the connection of 1-bit blt signal is going to 'help' ALU control to let ALU do the slt operation?
Isn't this the same ALU control mentioned in the lecture notes, where the only possible way is for ALU to do slt operation is for ALU control to have ALUOp input as '1X', then do slt for R-type instructions?

Moreover, isn't this just the same ALU control unit as in our lectures notes, where the inputs are only ALUOp + Function code, how is the extra blt signal going to connect? is it connected to somewhere internally in a ALU control, does it indicate it actually need to change something WITHIN the ALU control?
column16: Updated 1 year ago by Anonymous Atom
column17: I think Yigit points out exactly the issue :). Also if you read the question description it says you are given a "modified single-cycle datapath", meaning that indeed the datapath components could be different than the original ones.
column20: ~ An instructor (Alex Lam) endorsed this answer ~
column21:
Because of this part in the question text:

The encoding of the blt instruction is exactly the same as the beq instruction

beq instruction is an I-type instruction with no funct code. Therefore, the funct code will not be carried into ALU control (assume garbage input), and given the ALUOp is already filled up with other types of operations (and no slt except with a funct code in R-type instructions), we need to carry the signal that this is a blt operation to the ALU Control unit in this way.

Source: I did the same mistake as well.

column17:
Just add a bit more for choice D, in this choice you can construct a *NOT gate* by using (A NOR A), then with this you can have an *AND gate* by having (A NOR A) NOR (B NOR B), so that reduces to choice B (i.e. you have the AND and NOT gates using just the NOR gates). Since choice B is correct, this is also correct.

If you still find it hard to understand, please remember ( as we have mentioned in the lectures for many many times, and also quite obvious from the minterm/maxterm approaches), once you have the AND, OR, and NOT gates, you can build any circuit.
column20: ~ An instructor (Alex Lam) thinks this is a good comment ~
column21:
You can get the rest operation by de Morgan's law.

B: A + B = ~(~A•~B)
C: AB = ~(~A + ~B)
D: A nor B = ~(A+B) = ~A•~B

column14:
[fig1]
How is the line

Block size of 8 words --> 2^9 blocks come from?
column16: Updated 1 year ago by Anonymous Poet
column17: Exactly like Hong Ting has said :)
column20: ~ An instructor (Alex Lam) endorsed this answer ~
column21:
Total 16KB data = 4Kwords = 2^12 words
Each block is 8 word = 2^3 word

Total number of cache blocks needed to store 16KB data = 2^12 / 2^3 = 2^9
So in this case we need 9 bit for cache index, 5 bit for byte offset(as each block contain 8 word)

column14:
Hi, I would like to ask why the last forwarding happens between MEM of add $1, $2, $8 and MEM of sw $1, 4($7)? Why can’t it happen between add’s EX and sw’s MEM?
[fig1]
column16: Updated 1 year ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
The question says "Full set of forwarding hardware is available, from any stage to any stage (provided it does not violate the timing consistency)".
As for the question "Why can’t it happen between add’s EX and sw’s MEM?", this is because you can only forward in the adjacent clock-cycles. Imagine the cycle as weekdays, then you can forward at the end of Monday/beginning of Tuesday (end of cycle 8)to Tuesday.(cycle 9). But you can't forward at the end of Sunday/beginning of Monday to Tuesday. You need to think deeper to understand why this is not possible.

column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Helix
column17:
For 3B you need to provide an IF and ONLY IF (iff) proof.

You need to prove that A is Bitonic iff (3B) is true

=> IF A is Bitonic, you already know that a unique i exists. Proving (3B) means you must then prove the existence of i’.

<= If (3B) is true then you are given that i,i’ exist and are unique. What does that tell you about whether A is bitonic?

regards, mj golin

column14:
In Problem 2 of hw1, it is stated that "each call to gcd( ) does only O(1) work". However, it calculates n mod m and that require more than O(1) (A naive algorithm for division is O((number of digits in n)*(number of digits in m))=O(log(n)log(m), leading to a O(log(n)2log(m)) algorithm.)

function gcd(n, m) %Assume 0<m<n
1. if m = 0
2. return (n)
3. else
4. return (gcd(m, n mod m))
run code snippetVisit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets_
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
Our work model here is that the “mod” operation takes O(1) time. This is similar to assuming that other arithmetic operations, e.g., multiplications, addition, subtraction and division, require O(1) time (and is usually done in the informal RAM model.)

This is an implicit assumption but is not important because it has no effect on the actual problem. The problem specification was explicitly designed to make this unambiguous. It specifies that you should measure “the number of recursive calls made”.

This number does not depend upon the running time of the “mod” operation

regards, mj golin

Yes.

P.S. Formally, we view triangles as closed polygons (with three edges)

column14:
Dear Professor,

I just want to confirm if "item" in this problem means key, so in (II) and (III), the input is a key and we have to find the node(s) that contain(s) the key or insert the key in some node (respectively). If yes, if more than one node contain the key do we have to find all the nodes in (II)? In (III), are we allowed to change the number of nodes?

Best,

Rubab
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
I just want to confirm if “item” in this problem means key,
Technically, no. It’s an item. Multiple items may have the same key. This can occur with Binary Search Trees as well. An item may be a record and multiple records might have the same key.

But, if it makes it simpler, for the sake of this problem, you may assume that all items have unique keys.
Just specify in advance that you are using that assumption.

so in (II) and (III), the input is a key and we have to find the node(s) that contain(s) the key
Or some node that contains the key (if there are multiple such nodes). The same as for BSTs)


or insert the key in some node (respectively).
Not exactly. In this last case you need to create a new tree that contains all the old keys and the new key.

The easiest way to do this is to try to insert the key into the appropriate leaf and then, if the resulting tree violates the rules, fix that.

If yes, if more than one node contain the key do we have to find all the nodes in (II)? In (III), are we allowed to change the number of nodes?
No. The resulting tree must contain exactly all of the old items in the tree as well as the new item that has been inserted

regards,
mj golin

column14: if the number of swaps performed by both insertion sort and bubble sort are equal to the inversion number of the array then why is insertion sort considered better?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
From a purely swapped-based algorithmic analysis point of view, they're the same.

But, Bubble Sort is much harder to understand than the simple insertion sort and (because of that) also harder to code correctly. No contemporary computer scientist recommends it.

For many years it was taught as a first sort, No one is quite sure why and papers on computer science education have been written about this. See
https://users.cs.duke.edu/~ola/bubble/bubble.html

We absolutely don't recommend it
(We only introduce it in th etutorial to give you more practice in analysis; not as a recommendation for use)

regards,
mj golin

column14: [fig1] For Q1(a) (i) in HW1, can we follow this writing method (from one of the slides) to write the solution? If yes, then is it considered as using induction method? I thought it isn't because we are not writing in the "base case: ... ; General step: ..." kind of format, we just unfold all the terms and write out the exact total number. So I'm a bit confused with why Professor says it is using implicit induction? Thank you!
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Helix
column17:
1) yes you can use that method for (a) (i)

2) The unfolding required to show that the general step is correct IS an induction step

More specifically, the general statement is that
$$(*) \quad T(n) = 2^i T(n-i) + \sum_{j=0}^{i-1} 2^j$$

Showing that this formally correct requires induction.

The base case is that it is true for $i=1$.

Now assume, by induction, that (*) is true for $i-1$, i.e,
$$T(n) = 2^{i-1}T(n-(i-1)) + \sum_{j=0}^{i-2}2^j$$

Then, expanding using the basic recurrence shoes that
$$T(n) = 2^{i-1} (2(T-(i-1) -1) +1) + \sum_{j=0}^{i-2}2^j = 2^i T(n-i) + 2^{i-1} + \sum_{j=0}^{i-2}2^j = 2^{i-1}T(n-i)) + \sum_{j=0}^{i-1}2^j$$,
i.e, (*) is true for $$i$$.

This is classic induction. But we don't usually write this out formally, which is why we say that it is implicit.

The longer Algorithm 3 on the next page modifies Algorithm 2 by hardcoding in separate termination conditions for the cases m = 1 and m = 2: It is actually easier to justify than Algorithm 2, because lines 1-12 obviously are correct for m = 1; 2 $$\bf \mbox{(exhaustive search of all cases)}$$ and lines 14-20 are then easy to justify for the general case."

"Derive a Recurrence Relation" means to show how you got the recurrence relation.

For example, for max contiguous subarray, we showed that solving the problem on size n
could be done by solving two problems of half the size and $$O(n)$$ more work so
$$T(n) = 2 T(n/2) + O(n)$$

The derivation is the showing of why this equation models the running time of the algorithm.

The assignment problems then ALSO ask you separately to show why the recurrence you derived implies $$T(n =O(n \log n)$$ or $$T(n) = O(\log n)$$

column14:
[fig1]
What does it mean to explicitly identify values of c in (i)? Does it mean to choose a c which will satisfy the condition or are we supposed to derive a value for c? or can we use inequality?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
You can't just "choose" a value. You have to identify the values $$c,n_0$$ and demonstrate/prove that they work for that particular problem.

As an example, in (ii), the fact that $$S(3^k) = O(k)$$ means that you know that there exists $$c_1$$ and $$k_0$$ such that, for all $$k > k_0,$$ $$S(3^k) \le c_1 k$$

The problem is asking you to show that there exists a $$c$$ and $$n_0$$ such that
for all $$n > n_0,$$ $$S(n) \le c \log_3 n$$

Your answer needs to provide EXPLICT values for $$c,n_0$$ such that this statement is true (those values will probably have to depend upon the values $$c_1$$ and $$k_0$$).

As another example, in (iv) , you have to provide explicit values $$c'$$ and $$n_0$$ such that
$$T(n) \le c' \log_3 n$$ for all $$n > n_0$$

Note that, in this case, $$c'$$ might end up being a function of the input value $$c$$.


regards,
mj golin

column14:
For Q1(a) (iv), if I've already proved T(n)=O(log (base 3) n), could I just directly write T(n)=O(log n)?

Also, for Q1(a) (ii) and (b) (v), if I feel my base case and general case are highly similar, can I just write the general case? Thanks!
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Helix
column17:
> For Q1(a) (iv), if I've already proved T(n)=O(log (base 3) n), could I just directly write T(n)=O(log n)?

We already said in class that the base of the log doesn't matter.

So, proving that $$T(n) \le c \log_3 n$$ for all $n > n_0$ (which is what it means to prove that T(n)=O(log (base 3) n) IS proving that $$T(n) = O( \log n)$$.

Don't forget that you need to say what $$c$$ and $$n_0$$ are.

>Also, for Q1(a) (ii) and (b) (v), if I feel my base case and general case are highly similar, can I just write the general case?

No. You need to prove the correctness of your bases case(s) and then prove your general induction step separately.

I'm not quite sure how it's even possible (in a clean induction for these problems ) for the base case and the general case to be similar.
The base case is usually proving something like "my statement is correct for $$n=1,2$$;
the general case is usually that if my statement is true for all values less than $$n$$ then my statement is correct for $$n.$$

These are very different things

Please look at the induction proofs given in the solutions to the two problems in the practice homework for an illustration of this.

column14: The hint of Q2(a) claims that we could only assume that n≥2, but when n=2 is it possible to have a right-flipped array? I think it should be at least 3 elements to make such an array exist?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
Correct.

The definition even formally permits $$k$$-flipped arrays for $$n=1$$

As noted on page 5, If $$n=1$$ the array itself is $$k$$ flipped with $$k=1$$

There might be some misunderstanding here about the definition.
A size $$n$$ array has $$n$$ different possible $$k$$ flipped arrays,

For example, if $$n=2$$ and $$ A = [1, 2]$$
Both
$$A'=[1,2]$$ and $$A'=[2,1]$$ are $$k$$-flipped arrays (for $$k=2$$ and $$k=1$$ respectively).

Similarly, if $$n=3$$ and $$A=[1,2,3]$$

$$A'=[1,2,3]$$, $$A'=[1,3,2]$$ and $$A'=[3,2,1]$$ are $$k$$-flipped arrays (for $$k=3,2,1$$ respectively)

column14:
From the lecture slides, proof using induction has been done like below.

In order to prove that I(n) is true for all n >= 1,

Base case: Prove that I(n) is true for n=1

General case: Assume that I(n) is true for n-1. Using this assumption, prove that I(n) is true for n.

I am quite used to this type of induction, and was able to apply this technique for proving why my algorithm is correct for Q2. 

However, I find it hard to adopt the method that has been used in Practice Homework. Induction used in 'Practice Homework' sets general case as (Suppose I(n') is true for all 1<=n'<n).

Can I just use the previous method of setting base case as (Suppose that I(n) is true for n-1)? 

If so, can you kindly explain why the methods are the same? I get the insight why the two methods are the same, but can't understand the exact reason behind it..
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Scale
column17:
What you are describing is called weak induction.
The version I used is called strong induction.


(The name is bit of a misnomer since they are equally powerful. Anything that can be proven using the weak form can also be proven using the strong form and voce-versa)

If you can come up with an induction hypothesis that permits using weak induction, by all means use it.

BUT, when proving correctness of a recursive divide-and-conquer algorithm it can be messy to use weak induction. That's because problems of size n usually do NOT recursively call problems of size $$n-1$$. They call SMALLER subproblems. So, Strong induction is more natural in this case and I recommend using it.

All of the (informal) "proofs" of correctness that we have done in class have actually used strong induction.

http://www.cs.cornell.edu/courses/cs2800/2011fa/Lectures/induction.pdf
describes the differences between the two types of induction and
https://courses.cs.cornell.edu/cs2800/wiki/index.php/Proof:Strong_induction_is_equivalent_to_weak_induction
explains why weak induction implies strong induction.

If you have trouble understanding this please email me and we can set up an office hour meeting.

regards,
mj golin

column13: Any reference for writing explanation for algorithm?
column14: For questions like problem2 we are supposed to write descriptions for the algorithm we designed, Any example on how to write description for algorithm?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Scale and Loading...
column17:
This is just meant to be a brief description of the algorithm describing the basic idea behind what it does.
There's no "formalism" here (that's what the pseudocode description is for)
We do this a lot in class.


For example, a brief description the the divide-and-conquer algorithm that we learned for maximum contiguous subarray could be.

******************************************
The algorithm solves the problem on size $$n=1$$ by just returning the individual element.

The algorithm solves the problem on size $$n>1$$ by splitting the problem into a left half and right half and
-recursively finding the max contiguous subarray in each of the left and right halves
- it also finds the max contiguous subarray crossing BETWEEN the two arrays
- it then returns the largest (value) of the three

It finds the max contiguous subarray crossing the between the two arrays by
(i) finding the max contiguous subarray on the left whose right boundary is the midpoint
(i) finding the max contiguous subarray on the right whose left boundary is the midpoint
(iii) and gluing them together
****************************************************************

We ask for this description because the main idea of the algorithm will often got lost in the pseudocode.
We want to understand the basis behind your design.

This also makes it easier for us to mark unclear solutions. If your pseudocode is not understandable we will often try to figure out what it does by reading your cleaner description and then matching that to the pseudocode.

column14:
I would like to ask about the base of Logs which does not have a specified value for the base, such as the expression logn.

First, I wonder how we can manipulate them. For instance, in some calculations, it is given as logn but might need to be compare to some log function with a specific base, such as lnn. Should we directly change its base like writing logn = lognn? And from the other side, can be write 
lnn = logn? If there is an implicit base for such kind of log function, what is its value? I think the base of log does not matter when we are using asymptotic notation, but I am uncertain about the situation when we are simply manipulating them for calculations that does not involve asymptotic notation
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
When stated in asymptotic notation, the base can be left out because it does not matter.

This is because, for any constants $$a, b$$ we have

$$\log_a n = (\log_a b) \log_b n$$ and thus

$$\log_a n = \Theta ( \log_b n)$$.

i.e., in asymptotic notation, constants do not matter.
So we will usually write things like $$O(n \log n)$$ without the base.


On the other hand, there when doing actual calculations, you must write the bases of the $\log$s of you can get things very wrong.

For example if you are given $$A = 4^{\log_4 n}$$ and $$B = 4^{\log_2 n}$$ you can't just say that you can get rid of the bases.

Notice that $$A= n$$ but
$$B= 4^{(\log_2 4) \log_4 n} = (4^{\log_4 n})^{\log_2 4} = n^2.$$

so the base of the log was very important.

column14: Can we know how much marks each of the sub-problems of Problem 1 provide?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Mouse
column17:
We can't provide that information because most of the problems can't be split apart perfectly that way.

The different parts are to walk you through the solutions step by step and make sure that you provide enough information for us to know whether you have correctly solved the full problem
For example, problem 3 is really
"construct an $$O(n \log n)$$ algorithm for finding heavy elements''

So, how you do on one part can have a very large influence on how you are marked on another part.

For example, if your algorithm is $$O(n^2)$$ instead of the requested $$O(n \log n)$$ then the analysis of the run time will be wrong even if you say that it $$O(n^2).$$

While we do have our guidelines as approximately how much each part should be worth those are just our internal guidelines

column14: Which method of proof would be the best approach for Q.3.b? Is it compulsory to use induction or can we simply use direct proof?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Poet
column17:
I'm not quite sure what you are asking.

ANY proof of correctness for a divide-and-conquer algorithm MUST use induction (easiest to write using string induction).


The question would be whether you need to explicitly state the induction hypothesis, e.g., , that the algorithm is correct for all problems less than size n" or not.

My recommendation at this early stage of your studies is to state it explicitly.
That leaves less chance that you will make mistakes.

In practice, as you become more and more advanced it is assumed that everyone reading your proof KNOWS that this is an induction proof, so it's not necessary to spend time framing the hypothesis explicitly.

(This is similar to mathematics. The lower level the class, the more you have to explicitly prove small details. In higher level classes, the easier stuff is just assumed to be correct)

column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17:
You seem to have misunderstood the question.

The problem in the HW is Quicksort which compares items to a pivot. It does not Merge two sorted lists.

The problem in the TUTORIAL was Mergesort, which did merge two sorted lists.

You are supposed to draw a tree using the same format/structure/idea as in the tutorial but not using the same sorting algorithm.

Quicksort starts with items in the array as
$$a1, a_2, a_3, a_4.$$
The first Partition operation compares everything to the pivot $$a_4.$$
So, the first comparison is $$a_1 : a_4.$$ The second comparison is $$a_2 : a_4$$.

You are then asked to continue this process.

column14: For the pseudocode in the last page of the solution for tutorial question SS2, the while loop check the condition i<j+1. When I tried with some examples, I failed to terminate the loop, and I wonder if the condition should be i<j-1 or j<i+1 instead.
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
You are correct.

That was a typo. It should have been $$i < j-1$$.
Thanks for reporting it.

The algorithm maintains the invariant that
$$A[i] < \infty$$ and $$A[j] = \infty$$

At each step it decreases (halves) the size $$j-i$$.
When $$i = j-1,$$ $$A[i]<\infty$$ and $$A[i+1]=\infty$$ so $$i$$ is the answer.

column14: We are required to “explain why the algorithm is correct”. Is that means we do not have to formally proof it, i.e. by induction?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Helix
column17:
Your explanation has to be detailed enough to be correct.

If your algorithm is recursive, that ALWAYS involves using induction, at least implicitly, since you are showing that an algorithm works on a problem of size $$n$$ by assuming that it works correctly on all smaller subproblems.

So, while it is not always necessary to write out FORMAL induction hypothesis, any clear explanation will need to be structured like like an induction proof.

If your algorithm is not recursive then you still need a clear explanation.

************************
I'd strongly suggest that you structure your explanation as a mathematical proof by starting off with a statement of assumptions and then showing how you derive each step of your argument, using full sentences and mathematical symbols.

While this might seem like overkill, most of the incorrect solutions we see come about because students get confused about what they can assume and what they can prove. Making it formal reduces the chances of getting it wrong.

column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Poet
column17:
- It's $$O(n \log n)$$ not $$O(\log n)$$

Also, as stated in class, the term $$\log n$$ is undefined numerically since a $$\log $$ needs a base.

BUT, as noted in class, when using $$O()$$ notation we will usually NOT write the base.
This is because $$\log_a n = \Theta (\log_b n)$$ for all $$a, b >0.$$ Thus, the base of the $$\log$$ does not matter when using the asymptotic notation.

column14: In P2, Can I treat log(k) as a very small value? such that O(nlog(k)) be equivalent to O(n)?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
Absolutely not.
$$k$$ is a variable that can be arbitrarily large (only constrained by the fact that $$1 \le k \le n$$).

So, for example, if $$k = \sqrt n,$$ then $$n \log_2 k = \Theta(n \log n).$$

column14:
In Q3b, there are some requirement on the algorithm, and one of them is:

Use the black-box selection procedure to design an algorithm that is never worse (and sometimes better) than _(n log n).
Is that means we need to design a algorithm that is O(nlogn), and Ω(f(n)), where f(n)≤cn log n?

If we also need to consider the lower bound, do we need to provide a mathematical proof for that, or we can simply explain how the algorithm run faster?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
It just means that your algorithm is $$O(n \log n)$$
There is NO lower bound requirement.

But, don't forget about the additional constraint which is that if $$k \le n/\log_2 n$$ your algorithm needs to run in $$O(n)$$ time.

So essentially, you need to have that your algorithm runs in
$$f(n,k)$$ time
where $$f(n,k)$$ is a function that satisfies
(1) for all $$k \le n$$ $$f(n,k) = O(n \log n)$$
That is, for all $$n$$ large enough and $$k \le n$$, $$f(n,k) \le c_1 n \log_2 n$$
AND
(2) for all $$k \le n/\log_2 n = O(n)$$
That is, for all $$n$$ large enough and $$k \le n/\log_2 n$$, $$f(n,k) \le c_2n$$

where $$c_1, c_2 >0$$ are some fixed constants.

column14: In DC3 (c), don't we need to do partition also after finding the median Xm? So that when we call the function on the left or right side, we are sure that all elements are either smaller or greater than Xm?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
DC3 is not giving you any pseudocode. It is just describing how to solve the problem.

If you read it carefully it actualy IS implicitly calling a version of partition.

It is finding the median item $$x_m$$ and then
spending $$O(n)$$ further time
finding all items satisfying $$x_j \le x_m$$.

That means that it has partitioned the $$x_j$$ into $$x_m$$, those items less than $$x_m$$ and those items greater than $$x_m$$. In other words, it is partitioning on $$x_m$$.

column14:
Hello, I have a question about the definition of Tierce. It is said that Tierce(A, p, r) = BB(A, p, r, floor( (r-p+1)/3 )).

But for an array with 2 elements, it will be BB(A, p, p+1, 0). I do not think this is a valid input of BB since there is no 0th smallest number.

I think this should be change to ceiling( (r-p+1)/3 ) instead of floor( (r-p+1)/3 ).
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
No.
Tierce is undefined when $$r-p+1 <3$$.
(It's definition would be arbitrary).

So, if you have $$r-p+1 <3$$, i.e, your problem is size 1 or 2, you can't call Tierce.

You would have to just solve the problem using brute-force.

But this is trivial to do, because then you are solving one of the cases
$$BB(A,p,p,1),$$ $$BB(A,p,p+1,1)$$ or $$BB(A,p,p+1,2)$$,
all of which are easy to solve.

column17:
In mathematical terms, the problem states that you need to find a tight function $$T(n,k)$$ describing the running time of the algorithm.

You also need to show that
(a) $$\max_{k\le n} T(n,k) = O(n \log n)$$
(b) $$\max_{k \le n/\log_2 n} T(n,k) = O(n)$$

If your function $$T(n,k)$$ is non-decreasing in both $$n$$ and $$k$$ this is equivalent to showing that

(a) $$ T(n,n) = O(n \log n)$$
(b) $$ T(n, \lfloor n/\log_2 n \rfloor ) = O(n)$$

column14: I do not understand Case 2a: What does it means by “Base b_j is not matched in optimal solution for [i, j]”. In particular, what does “matched” mean?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Helix

The entire problem is about finding the maximum number of pairs of characters in the string that can be matched with each other.

Please look at all of the examples on page 22 and 23

You start with a flat string of characters b[1..n] and want to figure out the maximum number of pairs that can be matched satisfying the rules on page 23.

M[i,j] is the maximum number of pairs than can be matched if we restrict the problem to substring b[i..j]

case 2a is the subcase in which b[j] is not matched with any other character in substring b[i..j-1]

case 2b is the subcase in which b[j] IS matched with some b[k] in substring b[i..j-1]

column14:
I had a few questions when reviewing the huffman coding and hope to ask about them.

First, one of the steps in the proof is that we remove the smallest pair of siblings x, y and replace them with z. However, may I ask if there is always one and only one pair of siblings that we could pick? (is there only one pair at the deepest level?) If not, will the existence of other pairs affect the correctness of the proof?

Second, it is mentioned that the proofs for greedy algorithms usually require the use of greedy property. May I ask, for huffman coding, which specific lemma or part in the notes should considered as using the greedy property?

Thank you very much!
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Scale
column17:
>First, one of the steps in the proof is that we remove the smallest pair of siblings x, y and replace >them with z. However, may I ask if there is always one and only one pair of siblings that we could >pick?
Absolutely not.
For example, if all of leaves have the same weight, there will be many possible ties.

>(is there only one pair at the deepest level?)
Again no.
>If not, will the existence of other pairs affect the >correctness of the proof?


The proof is written very carefully.
It says that we pick A smallest pair of siblings. It doesn't say THE smallest pair.
Everything is written so that it will work in case of ties.


>Second, it is mentioned that the proofs for greedy algorithms usually require the use of greedy >property. May I ask, for huffman coding, which specific lemma or part in the notes should >considered as using the greedy property?
In this case it's using the properties all through the proof and not just in one place,
Consider the proof on page 20.
the use of Lemma 3 and the observation from page 17 are using the greedyness of Huffman's algorithm.

column13: time complexity of finding all connected component
column14: Hi, I’m writing to ask whether the time complexity of finding all connected component in a graph using BFS is O(V+E)
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17: Yes. It is O(V+E).Every time BFS(G) on page 9 is called, it is identifying a new connected component. So, BFS automatically finds the connected components.If you want to make this explicit, you can add a few lines that will label each vertex with a Component ID number.A simple way to do this is to give each vertex u an extra field u.ccIn the upper level code BFS(G) - Create a new global parameter CC# Originally set CC# =0Every time BFS(G) calls BFS-Visit(u) [note this is exactly when a new connected component is created] BEFORE calling BFS-Visit(u) Increase CC# by 1At the end, CC# is the # of connected componentsAlso, at the start of BFS-Visit(u), set u.cc=CC#Then at the end of the process, for every vertex u, , u.cc contains the ID # of the connected component to which u belongs.(Note that this only adds O(1) work for each call. So it doesn't change the running time of BFS)

column13: hw3 problem 3 what does quadruple mean
column14: in problem 3, we are asked to define a quadruple $$p_0^{(t)}$$, I would like to know what does that mean? in $$p^{(t)}$$ is t the power of p? is it just an integer? or is it a matrix?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
NO.

You can think of it a sequence of quadruples.

As an example, if you set $$p_i^{(t)} = (i+1) t$$ then

$$\left(p_0^{(2)},p_1^{(2)},p_2^{(2)},p_3^{(2)}\right) =(2,4,6,8)$$
$$\left(p_0^{(3)},p_1^{(3)},p_2^{(3)},p_3^{(3)}\right) =(3,6,9,12)$$
$$\left(p_0^{(4)},p_1^{(4)},p_2^{(4)},p_3^{(4)}\right) =(4,8,12,16)$$
...
$$\left(p_0^{(t)},p_1^{(t)},p_2^{(t)},p_3^{(t)}\right) =(t,2t,3t,4t)$$
.....


The problem is to define an INFINITE sequence of quadruples that has the property requested.

That shows you that, even for four matrices, the gain achievable by multiplying using the "better" parenthesization, is unbounded

column14: I found that all the examples from or Lecture notes fills the table from the smallest index to the largest index. I want to ask does that order matter, in other words, if I have a array A[i] of size n to fill in, it’s ok for a DP algorithm to fill in A[n] as the initial case, move to the left and return A[1] at the end?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17:
Not exactly.
IN the BST problem for example, we fill in A[i,j] by order of increasing SIZE l = j - i +1.

The idea in DP is to solve larger problems by using information known about smaller problems.
So, you need to fill in the table entries for the smaller subproblems before filling in the entries for the larger subproblems.

In practice, when you have a one parameter DP table A[i], i "usually" denotes the size of the problem, so you can't go wrong by filling it in in increasing order of i, which is why we do it that way.


********************************************************
Deeper Dive (not needed for this class but puts things in perspective)
In more advanced courses we sometimes view the DP table as a directed graph.

The entries in the table are the graph vertices and there is an edge from entry A to entry A_ if you need to know the value in entry A to calculate the value in entry A_.

The Directed graph MUST be acyclic. Otherwise, it would not be possible to fill in the table.

So, it's a DAG (directed acyclic graph)

Since it's a DAG, the vertices, i.e., table entries, can be topologically sorted (ordered)
ANY topological ordering of the table entries can be used to fill in the table,
That's because, in a topological ordering an entry A_ will only be visited if all the entries pointing to it have been visited, which means that all those entries have already been evaluated, which means that we have enough information to evaluate A.

The orders that we give you in class are always topological orderings of the table. They're usually not the only ones, though. Just the "simplest" to describe.

column14:
In the hints given in Problem 4, it is stated that the minimum height of a binary tree is $$\left \lceil \log _{2}n \right \rceil$$. However, I find from the Internet that the minimum height of a binary tree is $$\left \lfloor \log _{2}n \right \rfloor$$. Is there a mistake in the assignment?

Thanks.

Edit:

Oh! I see the difference. In the assignment n is the number of leaves while on the internet n is the number of nodes. Thus, there is a difference. Sorry for redundant question. Please ignore it.
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Calc
column17:
That was actually a very good question.

It turns out that there WAS a typo in the diagram in the hint.

The background is that there are actually two different types of BSTs out there.

The first keeps the keys in ALL of the nodes.
The second keeps the keys ONLY at the leaves (like Huffman trees)

We learned the first version in class, so the problem is stated for the first version.
The diagram (and the lower bound) illustrated the 2nd version.

That has now been fixed (the diagram and bound have been changed to illustrate the first version) and an announcement will be sent to the class about this shortly.

Thank you for reporting this.

column13: What are table values in DP
column14:
What does table entry in DP refer to? Is it something like e[i,j] and s[i,j]?

And in P9(b), do we need to make a DP table?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
>What does table entry in DP refer to? Is it something like e[i,j] and s[i,j]?
Yes.
DP works btydefining subproblems and then creating a DP TABLE, in which the entries correspond to the optimal cost of the associated subproblem.

>And in P9(b), do we need to make a DP table?
Every single DP problem in this assignment and in class and the tutorial "created" a table.

In 9 (b) you need to explain how you can use the values in the table you created to solve the problem.
In some DP problems, the final solution is a particular entry in the table.
In others it is the max (or min) or a collection of specific entries in the table.

column13: Are there any hint to do P7 proofs?
column14:
Because of the way L, T, and expected time are connected, I don't think any of the proof methods taught in lecture/tutorial fits the question.

column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Mouse
column17:
First try to solve part (a).

Now, for the remaining parts.
Suppose that an ordering IS optimal (min cost)

Consider what would happen if you swapped two consecutive items in that optimal ordering

- the new ordering can not be cheaper than the original ordering (which was optimal)
- You can calculate the difference in cost between the two orderings as a function of ONLY the probability and lengths of the two switched items. This difference in cost must be positive. This gives you a condition that must be satisfied if an ordering is optimal

You can then work backwards and show that this condition is sufficient as well as necessary.

column13: Q4 definition of "a tree does not exist"
column14:
In the rules of Q4, it is mentioned that if "a tree does not exist" then the table value $$e[i,j:k]$$ should be $$\infty$$.

Does "a tree does not exist" include cases where there range $$[i..j]$$ is not valid, i.e. when $$i > j$$?

So should the value for $$e[i, j: k]$$, $$i > j$$ be $$\infty$$ as well?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Poet
column17: >In the rules of Q4, it is mentioned that if "a tree does not exist" then the table value e[i,j:k] should be ∞.>Does "a tree does not exist" include cases where there range [i..j] is not valid, i.e. when i>j?No. It does not. If $$i > j$$ then the tree exists, but it is empty, so it has cost $$0.$$While this might seem arbitrary, this is actually how the recurrence taught in class worked.The issue there was that, when constructing $$T_{i,j}$$, it is possible that $$a_i$$ or $$a_j$$ is the root.In that case, the left or right subtree would be empty. The recurrence therefore needed the cost of that empty subtree to be $$0$$. This is why we set $$e[i,i-1]=0$$ in class.[Sidenote: Setting $$e[i,i-1]=0$$ was just a mathematical hack. BUT, introducing it meant that we didn't have to write out special cases of the recurrence when the root is the leftmost or rightmost item in the range. So, it was a useful hack.]The cases in which we nust set $$e[i,j:k] = \infty$$ are very different. These are cases in which the range of items is non-empty but the tree with the stated property can not exist. For example, the tree containing a range with 4 items ($$a_i, a_{i+1}, a_{i+2}, a_{i+3}$$) MUST have height at least $$2$$. So $$e[i,i+3:1]=\infty$$Again, this is a mathematical hack. You COULD write a more complicated recurrence that first checks whether a tree could exist before calculating its associated value. But, setting the cost $$=\infty$$ does this automatically.This is actually why we permit you to do calculations with $$\infty$$ in your pseudocode. In real code, that's impossible. You would need to keep a boolean indicator of the existence of a tree of that size and check that before doing a value calculation. Setting the tree value $$=\infty$$ lets you avoid that extra code.

column14:
In problem 4a, we are asked to give a dynamic programming recurrence equation, I assume it is the same as in lecture note 13 page 18
[fig1]
what does Don’t forget to provide the initial conditions mean? is there anything else we need to write other than something like the image?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by LEE, Chit
column17:
That is correct.
"Initial conditions" refers to the base conditions that need to be set.
These are the values that are NOT defined by the recurrence.

There are actually two slightly different types of initial conditions that can occur.

a) those that refer to the "smallest" base problems, i.e.,
$$e[i,i] = f(a_i).$$
These are the costs of the one node trees

b) Those that refer to boundary issues in the recurrence, e.g.
$$f(i,j)=0$$ for $$i>j.$$
$$i >j$$ refers to non-existent problem, e.g., the empty set.
Setting this $$-0$$ is saying that the cost of an empty tree is zero.
and makes the recurrence work nicely.

Both types are called initial conditions

***********************
A bit deeper. For this problem, (b) was not actually necessary.
You could have avoided this mathematical hack by not defining $$e[i,j]$$ for $$i > j$$ and changing the recurrence to

$$e[i,j] = w[i,j] + \min\left( e[i+1,j], e[i,j-1], \min_{i < k < j} (e_[i,k-1]+e[ k+1,j])\right)$$

Note that this new recurrence has peeled off the two cases of $$a_i$$ and $$a_j$$ being the tree roots and dealt with them separately. It's also mathematically correct and, possibly, more intuitively straightforward, but it's much harder to read. So, we prefer the version given in class.

But, both versions are correct.
column21: I believe that initial conditions refers to base conditions. In the image, that refers to e[i,j] = 0 for i>j and e[i,i] = f(ai) for all i.

column9: student give a possible reasoning and
column14:
I understand the process of greedy proof, but I want to ask for clarification if my understanding is correct.

In proving a greedy algorithm, we create(assume) an optimal solution which is different from greedy.

Then, we find the first position where the optimal solution is different from the greedy solution.

Then, we show that switching that element of optimal solution to greedy element is still optimal. This way, the length of the segment where greedy and optimal are identical has increased by 1.

For the remaining parts, we repeat the process above again. We find the first position where greedy and optimal differs, and do the same process.

Repeat the process until there is no element left. Here, we finally have an optimal solution which is exactly identical to greedy solution.

I don't really get the final step. Once I show the first one or two steps of switching and changing optimal into greedy, can I just say that "This process will terminate because we only have a limited amount of elements (n), and once this process terminates, greedy and optimal will be identical"?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Scale
column17: First. That is only one way of proving that greedy algorithms are correct.It works for some problems and not for others. For one thing, it requires that there be some natural way to order the elements of a solution. That's not always true. It wasn't true, for example, for Huffman coding and the interval partitioning problem.>I don't really get the final step. Once I show the first one or two steps of switching and >changing optimal into greedy, can I just say that "This process will terminate because we only >have a limited amount of elements (n), and once this process terminates, greedy and optimal >will be identical"? I can't answer your question definitively because the actual phrasing depends upon how you have set up your proof.One way to do it is to A) Assume that greedy is not an optimal solution.B) Let $$G$$ be the greedy solution and $$O$$ be some optimal solution.C) Let $$d$$ be some "similarity" measure between $$G$$ and $$O$$ In your case, you are letting $$d$$ be the "first place" that $$G$$ and $$O$$ differD) Create a new optimal solution $$O'$$ whose similarity with $$G$$ is greater.E) You then need to explain that the similarity value is bounded and if it gets large enough (explaining what large enough is) then $$G=O$$In some problems (E) is obvious and in some (E ) needs to be explained in more detail.That really depends upon what your similarity measure is.This proof can also be done by contradiction. You can define a similarity measure and then say. If $$G$$ is not optimal let $$O$$ be an optimal solution that has the highest similarity measure with $$G$$. You can then show that there is an optimal $$O'$$ with higher similarity measure, leading to a contradiction.

See https://piazza.com/class/kjv25fqyx8y513?cid=189 for examples of the use of the notation

>For the formula in (a), may I ask if each pi must be a function of both t and i and it can just be a function of t.

If it is just a function of $$t$$ and not $$i$$ then all of the matrices would need to be square
Because $$p^{(t)}_i=p^{(t)}$$ for some function $$p^{(t)}$$.

column14: In the example of optimal sequence where it said "A1..s[1,5] As[1,5] + 1..5 = ... ", why is there an addition of 1..5 at the end?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Poet
column17:
There are implicit parentheses there.


The idea is that we are splitting the multiplication into the multiplication of
$$A_{1.. s[1,5]}$$ with $$A_{(s[1,5]+1)..5}$$

$$S_{[1,5]}=3$$ so
$$A_{1.. s[1,5]}= A_{1 ..3}$$
and
$$A_{s[1,5]+1..5}=A_{(s[1,5]+1)..5}=A_{(3+1)..5}=A_{4..5}$$

column14:
In problem 5, we are asked to construct a DP algorithm to find the maximum sum of a path.

In the instructor's post posted on last Friday (@223), it gave us hints about solving recurrence by top-down approach, which is:
- Setting the base case at top level
- Denoting the recurrence formula as "maximum value of a path that starts from node $$(1,1)$$ and ends at node $$(i, j)$$"

However, after looking up some resources from the internet, I learnt that this problem can also be solved by solving recurrence using bottom-up approach, which is:
- Setting base cases at the bottom level

- Denoting the recurrence formula as "maximum value of a sub-path starting from node $$(i, j)$$, and moving down as deep as possible, satisfying the given conditions at the same time"

This made me raise a question: Is it acceptable for using bottom-up approach instead of top-down approach for any or all parts in this problem? Thanks!
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
While it might be possible to solve it bottom up, that's much more complicated to get correct than top down.


1) The statement
"maximum value of a sub-path starting from node (i,j), and moving down as deep as possible, satisfying the given conditions at the same time"
has no meaning. I really don't know what you intend.
If you wrote something like that in your submission we would mark it wrong since it's too ambiguous.

It's hard for me to answer your question since I have no idea what is being asked.

Does "deep as possible" mean to go all the way to the bottom level i.e., a vertex $$(h,j)$$?
If yes, write that. If not, I don't understand what you are suggesting


3) Please read the assignment rules carefully.
A "Path" is DEFINED as something that starts from $$(1,1)$$.
In part (b) and (c) the paths do NOT have to end on the bottom level of the graph.
They can end somewhere in the middle
If your recurrence is storing the value of the max path with the property that goes from $$(i,j)$$ to the bottom. That's not what is being requested. Using that to get the value requested will take yet another level of work


4) The problem was designed so that the technique you use for part (a) can be modified to be used on part (b) and (c) using the same basic notation and terminology. If you swap methods between the sections you will have to write a lot more.


The short answer to your question is that, while it might be possible to develop a bottom up solution it will be much harder and also much more complicate to write directly and almost certain to contain errors.

We strongly recommend that you use the top down approach.

column14: The hint in P4 mentions about the minimum height of tree given the number of nodes. I understand that if k < log(i-j+1) then the tree doesn't exist. But it is also mentioned about a special case when k=0. What I do not understand is that why does this make a special case? what differs it with the previous statement and makes it special? Please provide an example.
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17: Special case means that it is a special case of the the previous general ruleThe general rule is that if $$k < \lfloor \log_2 ( j-i+1)\rfloor$$ then $$e[i,j:k]=\infty.$$The special case arises because if $$i < j, $$ then $$j-i +1 \ge2$$ so $$0< 1 = \lfloor \log_2 2 \rfloor \le \lfloor \log_2 ( j-i+1)\rfloor.$$.Thus, as a special case of the general rule, if $$i < j$$ then $$e[i,j:0] = \infty$$

column14: do we know the height of the subtree by e[i,j] and root[i,j]?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
The DP given in class for optimal BSTs has absolutely no knowledge about the heights of the trees.

The intuition here is that the reason that DPS work is that they they throw away a lot of information when defining the subproblems. That's where their efficiency comes from.


$$e[i,j]$$ in the class notes is ONLY storing information about the minimum COST of a tree on $$a_i\ldots a_j$$. It knows absolutely no information about the tree that realizes that minimum cost (except for its root, which it stores in $$root[i,j]$$)

all these changes.

The way to think of it is that the $$e[i,j]$$, $$1 \le i \le j$$ are the actually table entries that we need to solve.

We set $$e[i,j]=0$$ for $$i > j$$ to deal with some boundary cases of the recurrence.

You can think of this as a mathematical hack.


In fact. the only time we access one of these entries with $$i > j$$ is when $$j =i-1.$$

for more details on this.

column13: Filling table with a starting value
column14:
Many of the DP algorithms seen in class start with:

"Let A[1..n,1...n] be a new array of all zero"

Is this operation considered to take $$O(1)$$ time? Can we fill the array with another number like, 1 or even $$\infty$$ or $$-\infty $$ using that same line (and take $$O(1)$$ time)? For example:

"Let A[1..n,1...n] be a new array of all $$\infty$$ "

Or should we initialize the array to all zero and then write a double loop to fill all of these $$\infty$$? (Which would take $$O(n^2)$$ time)
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Mouse
column17:
That's absolutely correct.
So, in the case above,
you CAN just write teh line "Let A[1..n,1...n] be a new array of all zero"
in the pseudocode.

When you're doing the time analysis, you just say that that line requires $$\Theta(n^2)$$ time. No need to do more for taht.

*********** Going further ********
In practice, when doing analyses in more advanced classes, we usually just ignore the time required to initialize the array.

The reason is that if the array has $$M$$ entries, your algorithm MUST do at least 1 unit of work per entry, so that algorithm requires at least $$\Omega(M)$$ time.

Since initializing the array only uses $$\Theta(M)$$ time, the initialization can't be the (only) dominant factor on the running time

column13: A question on DP and D&C
column14:
This question is not directly related to any problem in HW3, but I came up with this question in the process of solving DP problems in HW3.

In the lecture notes, it was mentioned that D&C used "top down" and DP used "bottom up". However, for Q5, we are recommended to solve the this problem with top down. For Q9, we are recommended to think about the last station first and derive a recurrence based on that. It is also kind of "top down". I'm wondering what is the substantial difference between DP and D&C. I'm quite confused with it.

Thanks!
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
There's a confusion here about what top-down and bottom up means here.

bottom-up means that you are
- defining the idea of a subproblem
- filling in the table from the bottom up, i.e., from smaller subproblems to larger ones.

So, you are actually solving problem 5 bottom-up
(you are looking at the graph from the top vertex $$(1,1)$$ down, on but that's just a visual aid).

You are also solving problem 9 bottom up. Filling in the smaller table entries before the larger ones


**************

The idea of top-down in recursion is that we are saying
I can solve this large problem by
- solving some VERY SPECIFIC supbroblems,
- and then combining the solutions together to get the solution to the smaller larger problem.

******************

In some ways, you can think of DP as top down.
You are solving the larger problem by looking at the solutions to smaller problems.
But, unlike in recursion, we don't know WHAT the exact smaller problems are in advance.
So we need to calculate ALL of the smaller problems before trying to solve the larger problem.

Top Down and Bottom-Up here are not meant to be very formal descriptions. They're intended more as aids to intuition.

column14:
I am not sure about what intial conditions mean. For example, in p4, we define e[i,j,k] on 1<= i<=j<= n_but we also let e[i,j,k] = 0 for i>j. Strictly speaking, there is no definition for e [i, j ,k] on i>j. Is it an initial condition? Simliarly, in P5, if I define v[i, j] as the maximum value of a path in the graph starting at (i, j) for 1<= j <= i, do I need to write v[i,j] = -infty for j > i as one of initial conditions?

-----------------------------

thanks for your answer, but I'm still not very clear that:

If I define v[i, j] without the requirement that 1<= j <= i, in this case I must write v[i,j] = -infty for j > i as initial condition? (becuase it is in my domain of definition) Otherwise, I could just regard v[i,j] = -infty for j > i as a mathematical hack?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
The initial conditions are the values for the variables that are not defined by the recurrence

Every $$e[i,j:k]$$ or $$V[i,j]$$ WITH LEGAL INDICES in the table must have a defined value

If they're not defined by the recurrence then they have to be defined as initial values

The reason that I wrote WITH LEGAL INDICES is because the table is defined for a set of indices.
For all of those indices, the value must be defines.
If the indices are outside that legal range you might decide to define them or nor (the reason you might want to define them is that they might help you write cleaner recurrences.

For example, in the BST recurrence, $$E[i,j]$$ only really needs to be defined for $$i \le j$$.
We define it for $$i > j$$ to make the recurrences easier. That's just a mathematical hack, though, and was arbitrary. It did not have physical meaning.

column13: Must the designed algorithm have a running time other than $$O(m+n)$$
column14:
Can it be $O(n)$ or $O(m)$
instead?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Beaker
column17:
The output table has size $$n$$. The algorithm requires at least $$\Omega(n)$$ time to write to it.
The input contains $$m$$ triples. The algorithm requires at least $$\Omega(m)$$ time to read them.

So, the algorithm requires AT LEAST $$\Omega(m+n)$$ time.

If your algorithm takes $$O(n)$$ time that means it has no dependence on $$m$$.
Similarly, if your algorithm takes $$O(m)$$ time, that means it has no dependence on $$n$$.
Neither of those is possible since it must be $$\Omega(m+n)$$.

******************************************
Note: We are only asking you to prove that your algorithm runs in $$O(m+n)$$ time.
From the above, if that's true, then you could really say that it runs in $$\Theta(m+n)$$ time.

column14:
If we have two possible paths of infection of a single computer (with different length) in the same timestamp, which path should we choose?

For instance,

Suppose that current timestamp is $$ t_7 $$, and we know that a set of computers $$ \left\{ C_1, C_2 \right\} $$ have been already infected.

Also suppose that we have these connection in timestamp $$ t_7 $$.

$$ (C_{1_{t_7}}, C_{5_{t_7}}, t_7), (C_{1_{t_7}}, C_{3_{t_7}}, t_7),(C_{5_{t_7}}, C_{3_{t_7}}, t_7), $$.

Here, $$ C_5 $$ can be directly infected from $$ C_1 $$, or it can be infected from $$ C_3 $$ which has been infected by $$C_1 $$. Since the infection is instantaneous, both infections will occur in timestamp $$ t_7 $$. Can I choose either one for $$P[C_5] $$ ?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
It doesn't matter. You can choose any one.

This is similar to Dijkstra's algorithm.
The tree Dijkstra's algorithm builds is A shortest path tree. There might be many such trees with many different shortest paths from $$s$$ to $$t$$
The algorithm breaks ties arbitrarily

The situation is similar for this problem.
The path from $$C_{a}$$ to $$C_b$$ in the tree can be any path that infects $$C_b$$ at the earliest possible time.

****************************************
Note. In your example, your notation is confusing.
Since you are giving an example you don't have to use multiple level subscripts. You could have just written

$$ (C_1, C_5, t_7), (C_1, C_3, t_7),(C_5, C_{3}, t_7) $$.

Is there a way to make node retain color or is this approach of building graph for epoch wrong?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
You may assume that every time you build a new graph the entire old graph disappears.
If you don't want that to happen, make that explicit.


The Build procedure only builds the adjacency lists for the graph.
It does not provide anything else.
If you want to associate colors with vertices, you need to create a new array that contains the associated colors.

****************
Observation.
If you build a graph out of $$m'$$ triples for an epoch, that graph has at most $$2 m'$$ vertices.
Thus, building the graph uses only $$O(m')$$ time and not $$O(n + m')$$ time.

column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Calc
column17:
Please see the response for
https://piazza.com/class/kjv25fqyx8y513?cid=363


The procedure Build(L) only builds the adjacency list, i.e., the linked list $$Adj[u]$$
You need to provide any other data structure that you use.

Since you are already using arrays $$Time[i]$$ and $$P[i]$$ it makes sense to use an array $$Color[i]$$ as well.

Otherwise you wil be accessing variables associated with computers in different ways, which can be confusing.

*************************************************************************

Note: You can't just use the off the shelf BFS or DFS code. It needs to be modified to also update the $$Time[i]$$ value of new computers infected in the current epoch.
Since you have to already slightly modify the code it's easy to replace $$u.color$$ with $$Color[u].$$

********************************************************

Note: One small complication that arises is that at each epoch of the algorithm, i..e, group of triples with the same timestamp, you should be building a new graph for that epoch.

But, that graph is only going to contain a subset of the set of original vertices
You are going to have to have set some of the initial conditions of all of the vertices in the CURRENT graph at the start of each epoch. This adds some small complications you should watch out for.

column13: Cut Lemma: Do we need to prove it in P1A?
column14: Can I just state cut lemma and say that every MST must contain edge e such that edge e is the min cost edge with exactly one endpoint in S or do I need to prove cut lemma before using the statement?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
You can use the cut lemma without proof.


But, the cut lemma only states that if $$e$$ is the cheapest edge with only one endpoint in some vertex set $$S$$ then $$e$$ is in every convex hull


What you want is the CONVERSE
That is
If $$e$$ is in the MST then there exists a set $$S$$ such that $$e$$ is the cheapest edge with exactly one vertex in $$S$$


That is different than the cut lemma. If you want to use that statement (which would be helpful for this problem) you will need to prove it

column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17:
Not sure I understand your math expression above as they are not typed using equation edition.

As stated in the lecture note 17_Shortest_Path, Page 39:

Page 44 further explains the two cases of the recurrence:

Case 1: $$k$$ is not a vertex on the shortest path from $$i$$ to $$j$$
=> then the path uses only vertices in {$$1,2,…,k-1$$}: $$d_{ij}^{(k-1)}$$

Case 2: $$k$$ is an intermediate node on the shortest path from $$i$$ to $$j$$,
=> path can be split into shortest subpath from $$i$$ to $$k$$ and a subpath from $$k$$ to $$j$$. Both subpaths use only vertices in {$$1,2,…,k-1$$}: $$d_{ik}^{(k-1)} + d_{kj}^{(k-1)}$$

The recurrence takes the min of the two cases.

If you are asking about $$d_{AE}^{(2)}$$, $$k=2$$ corresponds to only selecting intermediate nodes on the shortest path from {$$A, B$$}, and the $$k_{th}$$ (i.e., $$2_{nd}$$) node correspond to $$B$$.

column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Helix
column17:
First, when we say alphabet 
_
, are we referring to the possible set of characters of the text 
T
or the pattern 
P
, or even the union of them? I hope to know which is the case because I think it is possible that 
P
and 
T
use different sets of characters, which may not be a subset of each other.

And I am curious which set of characters we will use for building the state table, because I guess using only the set of characters used by 
P
can save some space. (anything not in that set will always go to state 
0
, so we can only put one column for that?)

The assumption in string matching problems is that 
_
is a fixed known alphabet. The elements of 
P
and 
T
are all in 
_
.

It is “possible” to optimize by only building a table using letters in the intersection of 
P
and 
T
but then you have the added complexity of how to INDEX your table (we assume that the characters in 
_
can be used as indices in a table that can be indexed in 
O(1)
time. That’s only possible if the alphabet is known in advance). Once your alphabet becomes variable then indexing becomes a cost as well.

We also only showed you the simplest version of string matching. There are many other algorithms, some much more complicated, and some engineered for different applications.

For example, the Knuth Morris Pratt (KM) algorithm is a variation of the one learned in class, but doesn’t need to build a transition table and runs in 
O(n+m)
time. It technically doesn’t need to know th3 alphabet in advance…

Besides, I am still a bit uncertain why the running time of building the state table is 
_(m3|_|)
. From the notes, I thought there are only three loops, so I hope to know where that extra loop comes from.

The table contains 
(m+1)|_|
entries 
_(q,a)

For each entry it checks, for all possible values of 
k≤(m+1,q+2)
, if 
Pk
is a suffix of 
Pqa,
and finds the largest such 
k

It takes 
O(k)
time to check this for one 
k
. So, it takes 
O(m2)
time to check it for all 
k,
i.e., to find 
_(q,a)
. So the total running time is 
O(m|_|)O(m2)=O(m3_)

column14: Can we assume that the original graph G is connected?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Mouse
column17:
The original graph is directed so the definition of connected is a bit ambiguous.

You may assume there exists at least one directed path from $$s$$ to $$t$$
(that’s in the problem specs).

If it makes it easier, you may also assume that, for every vertex $$v \not=s,t,$$ there exists at least one path from $$s$$ to $$t$$ containing $$v$$ (since, if not, $$v$$ is “useless”)

This implies that if you removed the directions from the edges and made the graph undirected, it would be connected. So. among other things, you may also assume that $$|V| = O(|E|)$$

column9: might be a good example, might benefit from giving examples and chain-of thoughts
column14:
[fig1]
I want to know if max flow |f| > total demand why the problem has no solution.
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17:
It is impossible for max flow |f| > total demand to occur,

Set $$S'= V - \{t\}$$, $$T'=\{t\}$$. Then $$C(S',T') = \sum_i dem(t_i) = \mbox{total demand}$$.

The lemma from class states that, for any cut $$S,T,$$ and any flow $$f$$,

$$|f| \le C(S,T)$$

In particular

$$|f^*| \le C(S',T')= \mbox{total demand}$$.

column14:
Anonymous at @444 wrote:

C(S,T)=∑ec(e)=∑e1=|E(S,T)|

.

This is what I saw in the discussion below the hint give. I don't understand why this statement is valid.

As far as I know, capacity of a cut is, $$ c(S,T) = \sum_{\text{e from S to T}} c(e) $$, not sum of the capacities of all edges. If we have an edge from T to S with capacity 1, the statement above will not be valid.

What I thought instead is, we need to prove that "cut" with minimum cut capacity is equal to "cut" with the minimum number of edges. It is the equality between cuts (set of edges), not between the capacity and number of edges.

Is my understanding correct?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
In the SPECIFIC problem we are discussing all capacities are 1.
So, the statement is valid.

***

The Max Flow Min-Cut theorem is about the CAPACITY of the cut.

But, in this problem, we can relate the capacity of a cut to the number of edges in the cut.
*******

In an S-T cut we do NOT include the reverse edges.
********

I am unclear as to what else you are asking.
If you have any questions I have not answered please re-ask them

What I mean is that suppose there are 3 nodes A B C and 3 edges AB, BC, CA. Initially if we use the DP for shortest path then all value to own node, i.e. dAA, dBB, dCC = 0. But suppose that AB, BC, CA all have negative value then wouldn't later we have dAA a negative value as the minimum distance? I just find it really weird to have this value if we are not moving anywhere from one node.
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17:
We actually shortly mentioned this in the slides at the beginning of shortest paths.

We specifically said that the algorithms don't work on graphs that have negative cycles (which is what you are describing).

The problem is that "shortest paths" don't exist (or can't be cleanly defined) if there is a negative cycle.

You can go around the cycle an arbitrary number of times and decrease the length more and more.

*********************************
Note. I may applications we can be sure, from the problem definition, that a negative cycle doesn't exist.

In other cases, we can run a negative cycle finding algorithm (this is a modified version of Floyd-Warshall) before running the shortest path algorithm. If it says that a negative cycle exists then we have to say tha the problem is not solvable.

column14:
I am completely stuck for P2 as I have no idea on how to formula the problem as a graph problem. There are so many inputs, what could be the correct way for me to fit the inputs to vertices and edges?

Could you please give me some hints?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
Reread the slides on bipartite matching applications again.

You can think of those as providers in $$Y$$ servicing people in $$X.$$

In class we learned how to solve them by building a flow network,

The flow network had two columns of vertices: one for X and the other for Y, with edges connecting the $$X$$ and $$Y$$ vertices if and only if $$y_j$$ could service $$x_i.$$

In this problem think of having columns for $$P$$ (people), $$X$$ (groups) and $$A$$ (advertisers).

You can draw edges between $$P$$ and $$X$$ if $$p_i$$ is in group $$X_j$$
and between $$X$$ and $$A$$ if advertiser $$a_k$$ wants to sell ads to people in group $$x_j$$

A path in the graph from $$p_i$$ to $$a_k$$ means that advertiser $$a_k$$ wants to sell an add to a person $$p_i.$$

Now augment that graph properly with a source, sink and capacities (part of the problem is figuring out the capacity values to use) and then show that solving the problem is equivalent to solving a max flow problem on the graph.

That should get you started

(and watch my Q&A session for "pictures")

column14:
In P1b, I think at some point we need to show that a cut with minimum number edges (which is found to be a min-cut) is a min edge separating set (*).

I am stuck at this point because we cannot apply the max disjoint paths trick here. I am wondering if I should prove that every edge separating set is a set of edges crossing a cut. Therefore, I hope to ask whether it is true and whether I should prove this to show (*).

If not, what should be direction I should consider in order to prove (*)?

Thanks.
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Mouse
column17:
That is a really good question.

You are the first person to ask it, so here is a hint

Let $$EC$$ be a a set of separating edges
Remove $$EC$$ from the graph $$G$$
Call the remaining graph $$G''$$

Now, create a new cut $$S,T$$
$$S$$ will be the set of vertices reachable from $$s$$ in $$G'$$
-- This is a cut because $$ s \in S$$ and $$t \not \in S$$ (because $$EC$$ is a separating cut

- Let $$E(S,T)$$ be the edges crossing the cut.
$$|E(S,T)|$$ is the number of edges in $$E(S,T)$$

******
(*) Prove that if $$(u,v) \in E(S,T)$$ implies $$(u,v) \in EC$$
******

If you can prove (*) you are almost finished because this implies $$E(S,T) \subseteq EC$$, so $$|E(S,T)|| \le |EC|$$
On the other hand, every cut is a separating edge set so, $$|E(S,T)|| \ge |EC|$$

This implies that $$|E(S,T)|| = EC$$

You can't use this directly because you don't know $$S,T$$


But, this will imply (similar to in (a) ) that a min cut found the FF algorithm will be a min separating edge set.
