column14:
I am still a bit confused about what information needs to be given and what can we get from Ford-Fulkerson in our algorithms. 

First, we have to describe the graph with capacities to pass to FF. How much time does it take to create this graph? $$O(E+V)$$ of the graph?

Then we can run Ford-Fulkerson on it, and the output is the max-flow. If we need the residual graph of it, can we say that we obtain it from the last step of FF, or do we have to create it again from the max-flow? If so, how much time does it take to construct?

Finally, the output seems to be a set, but adding elements to the set takes a lot of time using set operations. We know the elements are different (edges or vertices), so we can assume adding to the set is O(1) (since we don't have to compare to see if the new item is already in the set)?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17:
>First, we have to describe the graph with capacities to pass to FF. How much time does it take to create this graph? $$O(E+V)$$ of the graph?

Yes. It takes $$O(V+E)$$ time to create a graph

>Then we can run Ford-Fulkerson on it, and the output is the max-flow. If we need the residual graph of it, can we say that we obtain it from the last step of FF, or do we have to create it again from the max-flow? If so, how much time does it take to construct?

You can say that you get the residual graph from the last step of $$FF$$ (but it only takes $$O(E+V)$$ time to create it)..


>Finally, the output seems to be a set, but adding elements to the set takes a lot of time using set operations. We know the elements are different (edges or vertices), so we can assume adding to the set is O(1) (since we don't have to compare to see if the new item is already in the set)?

The output is not a SET. It's a LIST. All you have to do is output the items in the list.
Once you know $$S$$ and $$T$$ this is just outputting all edges $$(u,v)$$ with $$u \in S$$ and $$v \in T$$.

You've done that before in the last homework.
All you need to do is label the edges in $$S$$ as being in $$S$$ and the ones in $$T$$ as being in $$T$$
and then run through every edge in the graph and check, for each one if $$u \in S$$ and $$v \in T$$.

column13: p1b how to proof (S,T) is a cut with number of edges equal to maximum umber of edge-disjoint paths?
column14:
I assigned capacity 1 to all edges in $$E_1'$$ and capacity 2 to $$E_2'$$

I have proofed (S,T) is an s-t cut with minimum capacity.

I have also proofed that the value of maximum flow is equal to the maximum number of edge-disjoint path.

Then how to proof that (S,T) is a cut with number of edges equal to maximum number of edge-disjoint paths?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
You can NOT use the edge-disjoint path method for part 1(b)

You are not looking for min separating edge set
You are looking for what I call a min-$$E'_1$$ separating edge set

that is, look at all the separating edge sets that only have edges in $$E'_1$$ and take a set from that collection with the smallest number of edges.

You need to prove

- if $$(S',T')$$ is a min capacity cut, then $$E(S',T')$$ only contains edges in $$E'_1.$$

- That $$C(S',T') = E(S',T')$$ (this would follow from the fact that $$E(S',T') \subseteq E'_1.$$)

Since if $$S,T$$ s a cut, $$E(S,T)$$ is a separating edge set

This would then let you derive that

$$|f^*| = C(S',T') = |E(S',T')| \ge |EC|$$

You now need to prove that $$|EC| \ge |f^*|.$$


Ome way to do this is, given $$EC$$ create a new set $$S^*$$ that consists of all the vertices that can be reached from $$s_r$$ without using any edge in $$EC$$

Then $$S^*,T=V - S^*$$ is a cut.


NOW PROVE that $$E(S^*,T^*) \subseteq EC$$ (this is the main thing that needs to be shown).

Since $$S',T'$$ is a min capacity cut,
$$C(S',T) \le C(S^*,T^*).$$

Combining the pieces
$$|f^*| = C(S',T) \le C(S^*,T^*) = |E(C^*,T^*)| \le |EC|$$
(where the last inequality comes from the fact above that you need to prove)

which gives you what you need.

So, the total time is $$O(V+!E)$$ (or

column14:
I am a bit confused over why we can simply do n∑(1/n) = 1 to the R2 problem.

What if the hat was already given? Wouldn't the probability of later customers be affected? Why is Pr(X=1) still 1/n for all customers?

Hint says that "Independence is not needed for linearity of expectation" but I don't understand why
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Helix
column17:
We are NOT doing $$n \sum \frac 1 n$$

We are doing

(A) $$X = \sum_i Xi$$ (definition of $$X$$)

(B) $$E(X) = \sum_i E(X_i)$$ (linearity of expectation)

and then using the fact that

(C) $$\Pr(X_i=1) = \frac 1 n$$
This is just the probability that customer $$i$$ gets her own hat back

Which of those lines is causing you confusion?

That line about not needing independence refers to (B).

****************************************************************
This is the "magic" of linearity of expectation combined with indicator random variables.

(B) works even if the $$X_i$$ are not independent of each other.

column14:

column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
$$M$$ has size $$2n.$$


The intent here was to emphasize that the algorithm is doing a $$2^{n/2}$$ bit shift

So, adding $$V+W$$ to $$M[mid+1..]$$ denotes
adding $$(V+W) * 2^{n/2}$$ to the value stored in $$M$$

Adding $$U$$ to $$M[2mid+1..]$$, denotes adding $$U * 2^n$$ to the value stored in $$M.$$

column14: Compared with DP1 DP2, what’s the difference of DP over interval?
column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
These definitions are a bit arbitrary.

DP1 means a Dynamic program with one variable, e.g., $$V[i].$$

DP2 means a Dynamic program with two variables, $$V[i,j]$$.

The meaning of the parameters, $$i,j$$ are very problem dependent and the domain in which $$V[i,j]$$ is defined is also very problem dependent.

DP over intervals are a special case of DP2.
They model problems in which we have some linear order of items 1,2,3...n
and the domain is "intervals" $$i \ldots j$$

This is so common in practice that we give it a name "DP over intervals""

One minor issue with DPs is that, after finding the recurrence, you need to figure out some order in which to fill in the table. Again, this can be very problem dependent.

For DP over intervals, we can (almost) always fill it in the table in order of increasing "problem size'', i.e., interval size, $$l=j-i.$$
column21:
It is similar to DP2, but the difference is that it uses the window size (
l=i_j
). 

You can visualize the difference if you think about how the DP tables are filled in.

When we fill in DP2 table, we fill in the first row (
j=1 to m
), then the second row (
j=1 to m
), on and on (in terms of rows, it is 
i=1 to n
. We fill in row 
i=1
, from left to right (
j=1 to m
)).

When we fill in table for DP over interval, it starts with all cells where 
l=0(i=j)
then fill in 
l=1(i=j+1)
, and so on.

column13: Proof of correctness in the exam
column14:
If we use lemmas / algorithms from our lecture, do we need to provide all proofs of them explicitly?


For instance, if the questions ask about feasible assignment, modified max flow would be the answer. In this case, do I have to provide proof from scratch on: 1. Ford-Fulkerson algorithm (and all lemmas used to prove FF), 2. BFS (because FF uses BFS), 3. Why max flow = max bipartite matching, 4. Why solution exists when max flow = max bipartite matching = n. (Maybe I'm missing some, but I think at least these 4 are needed for the proof)

column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Helix
column17:
I think you misunderstood what was written.

"identify the lemmas/theorems you are using in your proof"
Just means to give the names or provide the lemma statement, e.g., I am using the cut lemma from class.

It is not necessary to provide the proof of the cut lemma in this case.


We distinguish between proofs which we ask you to prove from scratch, i.e., from first principles and proofs in which we tell you that you can use facts from class.
In the 2nd type, we want you to clearly identify what the fact is.

As we've mentioned a few times previously.
We are very aware that exams are time-constrained and that proofs are time-sinks.
We will be very clear in describing what must be written and what does not have to be written.

column17: Short answer: Yes, it is correctLonger answer: The Huffman algorithm says choose the two smallest remaining items and merge them. For the correctness of the algorithm, there's no specification as to which item goes to the left and which goes to the right. That's why the vertically mirrored tree would also be correct.

column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Helix
column17:
You are on your honor NOT to read anything once you open the exam.
That is part of the honor code declaration that you have all signed.

The zoom check in procedure is non-optimal and can stretch for a very long time.
If we allowed students to only read the paper once they entered the zoom room that would also be unfair, since some students will be admitted right away and others at the very end.

If we waited until everyone was in the room some groups might start earlier than others.

There are a lot of tradeoffs here. Unfortunately, there is no perfect solution.

column9: ________proof, might be interesting to look at the answers
column13: 2020 spring final exam p1 proof if i dont use $$g_{i}=min\{j'>g_{i-1}:y_{j'}=x_i\}$$
column14:
Can I do the proof without using $$g_{i}=min\{j'>g_{i-1}:y_{j'}=x_i\}$$

My proof:

I used induction to proof

The proof for m=1 to m-1 is same as solution

The proof for no false positive occurs is same as solution

Now suppose that X is a subsequence of Y, i.e. there exists some sequence of indices $$j_1<j_2<...<j_m$$ such that, for all
$$1≤i≤m, x_i = y_{j_i}$$. Then

$$j_1<j_2$$ so $$j_1+1\leq j_2$$

$$x_2...x_m$$ is a subsequence of $$y_{j_2}...y_m$$

$$\Rightarrow x_2...x_m$$ is a subsequence of $$y_{j_1+1}...y_m$$

In step c, when $$i = 1$$, the greedy algorithm finds $$x_1 == y_{j_1}$$.
After that, it is as if it is running the algorithm to find if $$x_2 . . . x_m$$ is a subsequence of $$y_{j_1+1} . . . y_m$$.

But, by the induction hypothesis, the algorithm gives the correct answer for this.

Thus, for $$m$$, if $$X$$ is a subsequence of $$Y$$ the algorithm will correctly report “success”.

Is the proof correct?
column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Mouse
column17:
The "bug" in your proof is that you wrote
>"In step c, when $$i = 1$$, the greedy algorithm finds $$x_1 == y_{j_1}$$."

The problem here is that there's no specification of which $$y$$ value the algorithm found to match $$x_1.$$ You need to claim that it finds the first one and then explicitly use that fact in the remainder of the proof.

Please see Problem 2 in
https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp3711_2021S/Tutorials/Bad_Proofs.pdf
for details. It provides worked examples of why this is an issue.

column13: Uniqueness of MST generated by Prim's algorithm
column14:
From tutorial notes, the MST should be unique for one graph.

However, considering the graph in lecture notes 16_MST.pdf page 11. In step ©, there are 2 choices for Extract-min, which are (b,c) and (a,h) as they both have a key of 8 and have previously visited in the for loop while the lecture note had chosen “c”.

If we choose “h” which is different from the note, as this vertex will not be visited again, would this choice generate a different MST? Would this violate the uniqueness of MST?
column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Scale
column17:
Just to follow up.

The MST is only guaranteed to be unique when all edges have different values.

We also only proved correctness when all edges have different values.


The algorithms will work even when the edges are not distinct though.
We actually noted this distinction in class. Please see the last page (p. 41) of the MST notes.


If some edges have the same value then there's not much we can say. The MST might be unique and it might not.. That would depend very strongly on the structure of the graph and which edges have the same values.

As a degenerate example, if all edges have the same weight, then every spanning tree is a minimum spanning tree.
column21: The Uniqueness of MST by Prim is only possible if the weight of edges are distinct (Pg 2 lecture 16). The weight of all edges are not distinct in the example slide

column14:
In the solution, the recurrence is defined as W_i = the largest sum containing the first i numbers.

Can it be formulated to W_i = the largest sum in a_1, ..., a_i such that the a_i must be included?
column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17:
>Can it be formulated to $$V_i = $$ the largest sum in $$a_1......a_i$$ such that the $$a_i$$ must be included?

You could, but it would then be more complicated.
Your recurrence would then need to know where the previous last item was so the DP would have to be something like

$$V_i = \max_{j \le i-2}(a_i + V_j) $$
where you also set $$V_0=0.$$

The final solution would be $$\max_i V_i$$

The big drawback of this new DP is that it runs in $$O(n^2)$$ time rather than $$O(n)$$ time.

column13: use of = and <- in pseudo code
column14: To represent equals to, both = and <- can be used when writing pseudo code?
column16: Updated 2 years ago by Anonymous Mouse
column17:
<- means "assigned the value"
"=" sometimes means "assigned the value" and sometimes means "equal in value to"

The meaning of <- is unambiguous.
The meaning of = is slightly ambiguous so we sometimes use <- instead.

We are not consistent about this in our notes, though.

column13: What things I can do to help weaker students in this course?
column14:
What things I can do to help weaker students in this course?

When I graded the exam papers, I felt heartbroken when I saw a student writing some negative sentences and could not answer most of the exam questions. 




In future, I think I can do something extra without adding the workload of my colleagues. It can be something small, but may give some immediate help for weaker students.




For example, will some video explanations accompanying with some slides to explain selected past papers helpful?
column16: Updated 4 weeks ago by CHUNG, Peter
column17:
I graduated from HKUST many years ago, so I can add a bit more history of COMP2011.

In the remote past (3Y curriculum), COMP104 (the previous code of COMP2011) is the first programming course for COMP students. The exam statistics were very high (mean: near 90). I was still able to secure an A range. It was stressful, but the learning atmosphere was good. There were tutorial classes (very rare nowadays) and I could ask past paper questions with tutors.

Since 4Y curriculum, more and more students with diversified backgrounds enrolled in COMP2011. I was assigned to other COMP courses and recently was assigned back to COMP2011.

I believe that the teaching team members are eager to provide better support for students, especially for weaker ones. Unfortunately, it is impossible to make some formal teaching activities because it is a 500+ enrollment course.

This is the reason why I would like to start something small but extra, and it can give some immediate help for weaker students.

It is not necessary to reset the values in the destructor because the attributes will be cleaned up and destroyed by the system when the object is deleted.

column14:
Pointer Arithmetic in 2D (or multi-dimensional) array

So far I understand that in a 1-D array, using the below example,
int x[] = {11,22,33,44};
int* xp = x;I know that since



xp + N == &x + sizeof(<type>) _ N, xp - N== &x - sizeof(<type>) _ N,
in the above example:

xp == x == &x[0]
xp+1 == x+1 == &x[1]
xp+2 == x+2 == &x[2].



However, what I don't understand is how this works in multi-dimensional array. I don't really understand what the lecture slide means. It is said that (in lecture slide, Pointer):




x == &x[0] != &x[0][0]




&x[j] == x+j




x[j] == &x[j][0]



Then, how am I supposed to know how to use pointer arithmetic to access every element in a 2D (or multidimensional) array? Since I have seen this kind of question in past papers (more specifically, 2016-Fall Final), I think there should be a method.
column16: Updated 1 month ago by Anonymous Beaker
column17:
See @220
The structures are different for a static 2D array and a dynamic 2D array.

column14:
Will there be any null pointers in queue? If yes, what is the expected behaviour if

1. all the elements are null pointers

2. some elements are null pointers

Thank you.
column16: Updated 2 weeks ago by Anonymous Beaker
column17:
There will be at least one valid student in the queue. There are no null pointers between valid student pointers. Consider the parameters in the function

void reorder_student(Student* queue [], int num_students)

if the num_students = 3. You can assume that queue[0], queue[1] and queue[2] will all be valid student pointers. queue[3] will be nullptr in this case.

You don't have to concerned about nullptr if you write your function correctly using bubble sort with the given parameters. The final output print function cout student data until it reach the first nullptr.

Fix your function's (in lab7.cpp) parameter type to match with the one in header file.

column13: ppq question - cannot convert int to float&
column14:
Hi~

I am wondering why the solution of this question says int could not be cnverted to float&. May I ask if there is a general rule for which data type can be converted to a reference variable of a data type~ Would float& only be converted from float, and int& only be converted from int etc~ 


Thanks~

Screenshot_2023-10-26_at_2.29.27_PM.png

Screenshot_2023-10-26_at_2.29.31_PM.png
column16: Updated 1 month ago by Anonymous Poet
column17:
In C++, when you pass a variable by reference, you are essentially passing the memory address of the variable. This means that any changes you make to the variable inside the function will affect the original variable.

However, you cannot change the type of the referenced variable. The variable type is determined at compile time in C++, and cannot be changed during execution.

column14:
After reading @154 and @158, I'm still confused as to what the return value should be if the player tries to perform an action (say a move action) on a destroyed robot. I understand that after a robot's hp becomes 0, it should be removed from the map and its hp value in the array should be set to 0 also, so displayHealthPoints will consider the robot not being alive. However, nothing is stopping a player to perform actions on a destroyed robot. Out of the 4 return value options for a move action, NOT_IMPLEMENTED should not be returned in a finished code, SUCCESS does not make sense since the destroyed robot should not even exist, let alone move to another location, and OUTSIDE_BOUNDARY and HIT_ANOTHER_ROBOT_ALONG_PATH do not make sense as well since that is not the situation (assume the move action would be valid if the robot was alive), so what should be returned? 

Since the main function only filters out robotLetter == CHAR_END_INPUT, any other invalid input for robotLetter (e.g. a robot that does not exist, so if only robots A, B, C are on the map and player tries to operate D) would still be passed through to the corresponding actionLetter codes and cause the same situation where the options for return do not make sense. Am I missing something obvious here?

column14:
In EC1(B), it is said that we may assume that n>=(k+1)^(1/2). I don't know how this could help us solve this problem?

Is it derived from n(n+1)/2 >= k? If not, I wonder how can we use this assumption?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
The formal definition of the max-contiguous subarray says that if all of the A[i] are negative, i.e., all non-empty contiguous subarrays are negative. The MCS is zero (this is the value of a subarray of size 0). This required some special cases in the code.

The definition of the k largest contiguous subarrays is a bit ambiguous if there are fewer than k non-negative contiguous subarrays. It’s unclear how to best define this. Should you pad with zeros? If you did, the code would need even more special cases.

To avoid that issue, we assume that the first 
k+1
entries are non-negative.
This guarantees that there are at last k non-negative contiguous subarrays and the ambiguity will not occur.

regards, mj golin

column13: Proof of correctness in Problem 1 and 2
column14:
Dear Professor,
Do we must use induction to prove the correctness of our algorithm in these problems? Or, can we explain the idea and why it works correctly in words? Thanks!
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17:
That really depend upon how clear your proofs are.
Normally, most proofs of this type will use induction IMPLICTLY without explicitly specifying an induction hypothesis.
That works if you can write very clear explanations.
If not, you will get points deducted for being ambiguous and not having a good enough explanation.
My recommendation to students is that they be as formal as possible at the start of the semester. As the semester progresses and they learn how to write clear proofs, they can become more informal.
As a side note

can we explain the idea and why it works correctly in words?
This question has nothing to do with induction.
Even if you don’t use induction you should still be using mathematical symbols to define concepts formally., especially in problem 1.

Most explanations I’ve seen that only use words are too ambiguous to be marked as correct.
In problem 2, there’s not as much need for mathematical symbols but you still need a formal partition of the problem into separate clearly defined cases and then show to recurse on those cases. That can’t be done properly just using words, It needs some formal structure.
My recommendation in general is to use both mathematics and words.
regards,
mj golin

column14:
I have several questions about EC2:

1. Are we allowed to add some attributes to the nodes of an AVL tree?

2. I think we cannot somehow "store" the current skyline vectors explicitly (as an insertion may take O(n) time, if the newly inserted one dominates all those inserted before). Therefore shall we add some additional other pointers something alike to the AVL tree?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Scale
column17:
Are we allowed to add some attributes to the nodes of an AVL tree?
That depends upon what you mean by “attribute”
AVL trees store records indexed by a key. If the attribute you are referring to is the full point data, then yes, you may store a point with its associated (x-coordinate) key.

If you mean expanding the AVL trees to store some other TREE data, e.g., a pointer to successor, the answer is
No. More specifically, you can use AVL trees as a black box.
But, if you want to change them at all, then you need to fully describe the changes and prove their correctness and running time).
It’s not worth it.

I think we cannot somehow “store” the current skyline vectors explicitly (as an insertion may take O(n) time, if the newly inserted one dominates all those inserted before). Therefore shall we add some additional other pointers something alike to the AVL tree?

Not true. The INSERTION into an AVL tree takes O(log n) time
Your problem is in how to MODIFY the tree.
That’s something you should be able to do with the other AVL tree operations that are described in the notes. There is no need to ADD new AVL pointers or operations.
Sincere regards,
mj golin

column14: In EC2, if i use a AVL tree, after the insertion part of the insert(p) operation, can i directly use the rebalancing algorithm with just a line “Rebalance()” in my pseudocode and claim the runtime of it to be O(Logn), without explaining the details?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17:
That is correct.
Since you already learned it in class, the AVL tree is considered as a “black-box” algorithm.
You can insert, delete, search, find successor and predecessor, split and join in O(log n) time without having to say how those operations work.
What is essential is that you use the exact format of the algorithm class used in class, e.g., if you use Split and Join, you have to structure the split and join calls exactly the same way that they are given in the class notes.
regards,
mj golin
column21: I think we don't have even to write rebalance() in pseudocode, because the operation of rebalancing is included in the operation insert() and it takes O(logn) time.

column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
Q1E) It means that, for EVERY 
n>2
you must explicitly define a different point set 
Pn
.

Let 
S(n)
be the running time of the algorithm on that particular point set 
Pn
. You then need to show that 
S(n)=_(n2)

Note that you have already proven that 
S(n)=O(n2).
So, to prove that 
S(n)=_(n2)
you only still need to prove that 
S(n)=Ω(n).

Q2) No. The master theorem does not assume that n is a power of 2.
Please read the master theorem again. The explanation there explicitly discusses this.

Q4) The problem requires summing values.

A closed formula means that your final solution can not contain a summation symbol. For example, we would not accept an answer of the form 
∑i=1ni
. You would have to write 
n(n+1)/2.

regards, mj golin

column14:
Question 1 ask for the tight asymptotic bounds, but saying that the result should be in format $$T(n:d)=O(n^{\alpha}(\log{n})^\beta)$$. So am I going to find the tight bounds or upper bounds?

If it's supposed to find the tight bounds, how can I prove $$T(n:d)=\Omega (n^{\alpha}(\log{n})^\beta)$$ given (2) and (3) are $$\leq $$? I have already proved $$T(n:d)=O(n^{\alpha}(\log{n})^\beta)$$.
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
Tight here means the tightest possible bound you can derive in the given format from the given information.

For example, if 
T(n)=n2(log2_b)3+n
then 
T(n)=O(n2(log_b)3)
is tight

but 
T(n)=O(n3(log_b)3)
and 
T(n)=O(n2(log_b)4)
, while formally correct, are not tight.

regards, mj golin

column14:
Typically in P2 in Practice problem tutorial 1: 
I find it difficult to find the subproblem sizes because it involves floor func, ceiling func, inequality, +1,-1 and so on. I usually list some examples and try to find the relationship, but sometimes it is time consuming.
So I want to know is there any common mathematical method to find subproblem size? Thanks
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
The floors _ _ and ceiling _ _ ARE the standard mathematical method.
A valid FORMAL mathematical analysis from scratch requires writing them down and working through the details.
In general, when designing algorithms using divide and conquer methods though, we
turn a blind eye to the extra complexities and write, e.g., n/2 instead of
_n/2_ and _n/2_
That’s because the standard techniques and theorems we use are written to handle all of those cases and permit us to ignore them.
So, when doing the analysis in real life , we explicitly use the standard theorems, such as the Master Theorem (which you will learn later) and ignore those issues.
In class assignments, we will usually explicitly tell you to only analyze when n is a power of 2, or 3, or whatever is appropriate, so that you can understand how the algorithm works without having to think about that extra complexity. (Although, in the first assignment, we will explicitly ask you to work through the details in the general case, so you can see the complexities that do arise in real life, so that you are aware of what you are ignoring)
regards,
MJ Golin

column14:
The selection sort algorithm given in lecture notes swaps everytime A[i] > A[j]

Is there any benefit of doing this as compared to the basic way of just going through the array and keeping track of the smallest element and swapping once at the end?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Mouse
column17:
The selection sort algorithm given in lecture notes swaps everytime A[i] > A[j]
Is there any benefit of doing this as compared to the basic way of just going through the array and >keeping track of the smallest element and swapping once at the end?

No. there is no intrinsic benefit to doing it this way.
In this first class we were trying to keep things simple, show you two different algorithms and then compare them. To do this, we wanted to keep the algorithms as similar as possible. So, we wrote both Insertion and Selection Sort as completely swap-based algorithms.
We could have written them differently, but then they wouldn’t have been as easy to compare.
regards,
mj golin
P.S. As the other comment noted, restricting ourselves to only using swaps is also conceptually similar.
column21:
We care about asymptotic performance. As the two methods both yield 
_(n2)
running time, there isn’t any substantial difference. It’s intuitive that in some cases (reverse ordering) the in-class method can lead to a large number of swapping. Though in my opinion, the cost of swapping in a RAM model (assume elements fit in a word) is constant, while the cost of comparing can be large. But to be honest, only finding and swapping two elements per run sounds conceptually simpler to me.

column14:
I realized that if we use binary search in the sorted part of the array, we can achieve O(NlogN) comparisons. But due to the nature of arrays, the number of swaps is still N squared.
I wonder if there’s a way to reduce the number of swaps. Changing the array to a linked list does not work (no binary search!). Is it possible to use more space to achieve that? If not, why?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
The answer is yes and no __

As you noted, we CAN binary search, using 
log_i
comparisons, to find the location in which to insert the i’th item

Summed over ALL insertions, this would require 
∑i=1nlog_i=O(nlog_n)
comparisons in total.

But, due to the nature of arrays, we might have to do 
i_1
moves (shifts) to insert the i’th item, leading to 
_(n2)
moves (shifts) overall.

So, this wouldn’t be a good overall sorting algorithm.

But, there IS a way to be clever about the shifting. If we keep the items in a balanced binary search tree (which also uses only 
O(n)
space) rather than an array we can do the updates in 
O(log_i)
time (comparisons AND moves) per step as well, leading to 
O(nlog_n)
total work. We’ll see how to do this later in the semester with AVL trees.

-Using AVL trees for sorting is overkill, though. We will soon see Mergesort and Heapsort which both require only 
O(nlog_n)
total work… Those are better than any version of Insertionsort can be engineered to be.

regards, m golin

We’ll see examples later that illustrate what is going on.

For example, we’ll see an algorithm for integer multiplication of 2 n-bit numbers that will, physically, run in time 
_(n_)
where 
_=log2_3
.

While this seems weird, the 
log2_3
reflects the physical reality of how the divide-and-conquer procedure works.

mi

i
.

m1+m2+_+mk=m,

The basic idea is to show that, if you know the list of infected computers before epoch 
i
, you can use a modified form of BFS to figure out which computers are infected in epoch 
i
in 
O(mi)
time.

This will require 
∑iO(mi)=O(∑imi)=O(m)
time in total

column13: Do we need to use formal induction for P2?
column14: Do we need to use formal induction for proving our pseudocode in P2?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Gear
column17:
You don’t need FORMAL induction,

But, if you don’t structure your argument SIMILARLY to formal induction it will most probably be wrong.

That is, you probably want to prove something like;

“Assume that my algorithm has correctly identified the computers infected BEFORE the start of processing an epoch. I will show that it has then correctly identified the computers infected at the end of processing that epoch.”"

That’s induction even if you don’t formally write the words induction

It would be difficult to prove correctness of your algorithm if you don’t have a structure that is functionally equivalent to that.

column14:
I am still struggling in building the 2nd algorithm of P2 which assume same ti. I don't understand how we can use BFS to solve the problem. Could you give some hints on how to do it?

At first, we build an adjacency list from the triples using Build(L), but what should we do next after that?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Atom
column17:
The second problem assumes that you have only one infected computer 
Ca
and all the 
ti
are the same.

Build a graph out of all of the edges in the triples.

Now run BFS starting from 
a
. A computer 
v
will be infected if there is a path from 
a
to 
v
n the graph (i.e., 
a
and 
v
are in the same connected component of the graph).

This just means that if you start the BFS at 
a
it will find the paths n(the BFS tree) to all the computers that can be infected with triples that start at 
a

Now think about how you can modify this if you start with more than one infected computer. The main observation you can start with is that a computer will become infected if and only if it is in the same connected component as some previously infected computer.

column14:
So given the hint, it seems to me that "m" is THE thing that matters in the runtime.

One triple creates an edge connecting two vertices. It's meaningless to add unexchanged vertices, so there won't be any vertices without any edge. Thus, the # of edges is AT LEAST half of the # of vertices. O(m+n) can be effectively written as O(m).

One might argue that m can be pretty small when not all computers have exchanged. But remember we don't even have to take those unexchanged computers into account.

So the question is: why O(m+n) instead of O(m) for this particular problem?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Loading...
column17:
Because you need to do 
O(n)
work at the beginning to set up the 
Time[]
and 
P[]
tables,

If the number of computers in the system outweighs the number of connections, then the 
O(n)
term is dominant.

In the worked example of djikstra algorithm, I wonder if it returns the shortest path possible? Because in the example given, wouldn't it be shorter to choose edge (c,i) instead of (h,i)? 

From this example, I can also find similar problem using prim's algorithm since edge (a,h) and (b,c) have the same length. If I choose edge (a,h) first instead of (b,c) using prim's algorithm then I would choose edge (h,i) instead of (c,i) which makes it not the shortest path possible. I wonder if there is anything wrong in my understanding.
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Poet
column17:
I don’t understand your question

In The Dijkstra worked example slides, the path from a to i through c is

a->b->c->i which has length 4+8+5 = 17

The path from a to i through h is

a->h -> i which has length 8+7 =12

The 2nd one is cheaper

In the Prim’s example slides we explicitly said that you COULD choose (a,h) instead of (b,c). That’s a tie, and ties could be broken arbitrarily. If you chose (a,h) instead of (b,c) you would get a different MST, but with the same cost

(Since this graph has repeated edged weights, the MST does not have to be unique)

column14:
Do we simply need to write algorithm in numbered point notation for (i) or do we need to describe other things as well?

Since I think P1 (a) only takes around 5 lines and I am not sure if we can simply write it and go for proof
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
You can write the algorithm in “numbered point notation” but you need to provide all of the detail in each point,
For example, you need to DESCRIBE what the flow network you build from the graph is.
As another example, if you use the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm to find a min-capacity cut, you need to explain how to do that. You don’t need to explain how the FF algorithm works. But, the output of the FF algorithm is a max flow. If you want to use that output to find a min capacity cut you need to explain how to do that. (This is implicit in the poof of the Max-Flow min-cut theorem but you need to extract that technique).

column14: For P2, if the ford-fulkerson algorithm is used, do we need to prove that the F-F algorithm correctly outputs the max flow for the graph?
column16: Updated 3 years ago by Anonymous Comp
column17:
NO. Similar to what was shown in the Applications and Matchings slides you may assume that algorithm outputs A Max Flow (there can be many max flows)
P2 is a modelling problem. You assume that you are given a tool that takes specified inputs, in this case the FF algorithm, and show how to model the problem so as to solve it using the tool.
Most of the applications we showed also explicitly used the fact that if the capacities are integers, the FF algorithm outputs a Max flow in which all of the flow values are integers. If you need that fact for the HW, you need to explicitly state that fact and where it is being used.

column14:
[fig1]
I am not sure why can numerical constants can pass to functions defined using non-constants as parameters and can still produce the output. I remember if the function is defined to take constant parameters, it can take constants and non-constants (but making it cannot change in the function). On the other hand, if I defined the function to take non-constants, it should have error if I call the function giving numerical constants. 

I just types the above code for asking this question, I know its not calculating the correct sum:)

Can anyone help me with this? Thanks a lot!
column16: Updated 1 month ago by Anonymous Scale
column17:
Constant parameters in C++ are not exactly in correlation with the constants (1, 2, 3, 4) in your code.

If you flag some parameters for some functions as constant by adding keyword “const”, the only effect happens when you try to assign a new value to this parameter within this function. The compiler will throw out an error and terminate your runnig code.

“const” works more like a reminder for the programmer, to force the programmer not to assign new values to this parameter.

It is very common to confuse “const” with pass by value/pass by reference. And there are arguments that if you pass by value, no matter what you do within the function, the original copy outside the function is intact. Why do we need “const”?

It is a very good question, and such reasoning is absolutely correct. So I recommend you to read this note to understand why we need “const” on top of pass by value/reference.

column14:
Hi

I dont understand why both of int j; int k; in the first two lines of main(),
are declared the same time, but have a different scope.
My understanding is that they would apply to S1,S2,S3,S4,S5 and S6
[fig1]
column16: Updated 1 month ago by Anonymous Mouse
column17:
The key point here is that there are three j defined here in this code snippet.

Every time you define a variable, this new definition will override the existing definition in the inner scope.

But when you exit the inner scope (get out of a pair of curly bracket), the variable defined in ths inner scope is discarded and you will refer back to the previously defined one.
column20: ~ An instructor (Jiajun Zha) endorsed this answer ~
column21: The j in the first two lines would have applied to S2, S3, and S4 if there were no j declared in S2 and S4. Variables in an inner scope override variables of the same name in the outer scope temporarily inside the inner scope.
